_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Lyondell Chemical Company

Channelview Operations (CVOS)

2520 Sheldon Road

Channelview, TX 77530



Risk Management Plan Executive Summary 3/21/2012



1.0 Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



At the Lyondell Channelview Plant (CVOS) we are committed to operating and maintaining our processes to protect our employees, the public, and the environment.  We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to ensure continued operations with protection in environmental, health and safety (EHS) protection in mind.  This document provides a brief overview of our comprehensive risk management activities to prevent or eliminate the possibility of an accidental release of a regulated chemical.



It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent the release of a regulated substance, however, if such a release does occur, our trained emergency response personnel are at hand to control and mitigate the effects of any release.   We are also coordinated with the Houston area Channel Industries Mutual Aid (CIMA) organization, which provides additional emergency response expertise.





2.0 Stationary Source  and Regulated Substances



Our facility produces a number of products that include Propylene Oxide (PO), Styrene Monomer (SM), Methyl Tertiary Butyl Ether (MTBE), Polyether Polyols (Polyols), and an assortment of products from the Butanediols (BDO) unit, including Allyl Alcohol (AA).  There are two POSM units, one MTBE unit, one Polyols unit, and one BDO unit.  These operating units utilize the following chemicals that have been identified by the EPA as having the potential to cause significant off-site consequences in the event of their substantial accidental release:



Toxics



Propylene Oxide (PO): Approximately 35 million lbs. are on-site based on storage, production and use.  PO is the major product of the CVOS facility and is also a feedstock for the Polyols and BDO producti

on units.



Allyl Alcohol (AA): Approximately 4.5 million lbs. are on-site based on storage and production.  AA is a product produced in the BDO unit.



Ethylene Oxide (EO): Approximately 1.5 million lbs. are stored and used on-site.  EO is a primary feedstock of the Polyols unit.



Annhydrous Ammonia (NH3): Approximately 140,000 lbs. of NH3 are stored on-site to be utilized in the control of Nitrogen Oxides (NOX) in the Utilities area. 



Flammables



Propylene: Approximately 950,000 lbs. are stored and used on-site.  Propylene is the primary feedstock for both of the PO units.



Propane: Approximately 75,000 lbs. are stored and used on-site.  Propane is a chemical used in the manufacture of PO.



Methylamine (MA): Approximately 925,000 lbs. are stored and used on-site.  The Methylamine is stored in an aqueous solution that is approximately 50% MA and 50% water.  MA is a feedstock in the BDO unit.



Ethylene:  Approximately 70,000 lbs. are contained in a pipeline and is used as a primary feedstock for the production of Ethylbenzene in the two POSM units.



Isobutylene: Approximately 414,000 lbs. are contained in a surge drum in the MTBE unit.  Isobutylene is an intermediate chemical used in the production of MTBE.



Our accidental release prevention programs and our contingency planning efforts help us effectively manage the hazards that are posed to our employees, the public, and the environment by our use of these chemicals.





Regulated Toxic Chemicals



Worst-Case Scenario Propylene Oxide (PO)



The worst-case scenario for PO assumes the complete rupture of the largest PO storage tank at this facility, releasing 17,250,000 lbs. of liquid PO into a containment dike, and leading to a vapor cloud release.  Distance to the endpoint of this scenario was calculated using the EPA tables of 7.4 miles, and ultimately impacted an estimated 90,000 people.



Credit was taken for the dike where the PO tank is located, reducing the immediate impact of the rele

ase to the environment.



Alternate Release Scenario Propylene Oxide  (PO)



The alternative release scenario for PO assumes failure of a 6 inch transfer line.  This release scenario also assumes the release would not be controlled for at least 15 minutes and that all other active safety systems fail, including the emergency shutdown.  The total release would be 20,700 lbs. of PO, traveling approximately 0.59 mi.  The release would affect approximately 300 off-site residents in the neighborhood abutting the facility.



Credit was not taken for the following added safety systems that would in effect minimize the release:

* Emergency shutdown procedures

* A chemical sump

* Sprinkler system

* Deluge system

* Remote isolation valves





Alternate Release Scenario Allyl Alcohol (AA)



The alternate release scenario for AA assumes a failure of a 6 inch loading line.  This release scenario also assumes the release would not be controlled for 15 minutes and all active safety systems fail including the emergency shutdown.  The total release would be 21,500 lbs. of AA, traveling approximately 0.62 mi. The release would affect approximately 350 off-site residents in the neighborhood abutting the facility.



Credit was not taken for the following added safety systems that would in effect minimize the release:

* Emergency shutdown procedures

* A chemical sump

* Sprinkler system

* Deluge system

* Remote isolation valves



Alternate Release Scenario Ethylene Oxide (EO)



The alternate release scenario for EO assumes a failure of a 6 inch loading line.  This release scenario also assumes the release would not be controlled for 15 minutes and all active safety systems fail including the emergency shutdown.  The total release would be 19,900 lbs. of EO, traveling approximately 1.6 mi. The release would affect approximately 4500 off-site residents in the neighborhood abutting the facility.



Credit was not taken for the following added safety systems that would in e

ffect minimize the release:

* Emergency shutdown procedures

* A chemical sump

* Sprinkler system

* Deluge system

* Remote isolation valves



Alternate Release Scenario Ammonia (NH3)



The alternate release scenario for NH3 assumes a failure of a 3 inch loading line.  This release scenario also assumes the release would not be controlled for 20 minutes and all active safety systems fail including the emergency shutdown.  The total release would be 12,400 lbs. of NH3, traveling approximately 0.5 mi. The release would affect approximately 300 off-site residents in the neighborhood abutting the facility.



Credit was not taken for the following added safety systems that would in effect minimize the release:

* Emergency shutdown procedures

* A chemical sump

* Sprinkler system

* Deluge system

* Remote isolation valves



Regulated Flammable Chemicals



Worst-Case Scenario Isobutylene



The worst-case scenario for flammables assumes the complete rupture of the isobutylene surge drum, releasing 414,000 lbs. of Isobutylene into an undiked area, leading to a vapor cloud explosionand overpressure.  The overpressure would extend  beyond the fenceline 0.6 mi. and affect approximately 250 people.



Alternate Release Scenario Propylene



The alternate release scenario for flammables assumes a flange spearation on a 12 inch propylene recycle line.  The scenario also assumes that the release would not be controlled for 15 minutes and that all active safety systems fail.  The total release would be approximately 163,000 lbs. of Propylene, leading to a vapor cloud explosion and overpressure.  The over pressure would not be contained on-site, and would also have a direct impact on a Cogeneration Plant owned and operated by Dynegy within the battery-limits of this facility.  The total affected poppulation would be approximately 325 people.





General Accident Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



Lyondell Chemicals Channelview Operations

(CVOS) has taken the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set forth under 40 CFR Part 68.  Addiitonally, this facility was designed and constructed in accordance with strict internal engineering standards as well as is subject to the requirements under 29 CFR 1910.119  Process Safety Management.



Process Safety Information: Chemical hazard, process technology, and equipment information is documented, kept up-to-date, and made available to operating personnel.



Process Hazards Analyses (PHAs): A rigorous practice of reviewing new processes or changes to existing processes at the design stage, with the overall thougth of identifying and mitigating HSE issues before installation or operation.  Scheduled PHAs are conducted every 5 years to revalidate previous hazard reviews and recommend corrective actions to prevent accidents.



Operating Procedures: Operating procedures provide detail on how to safely operate a process and are kept up-to-date constantly thru a review during any SOP training opportunity.  Operating procedures are based on process hazard / risk reviews and are periodically modified after completed of a process PHA.  Operating procedures include safe start-up and emergency shutdown of a process unit.



Operator Training / Certification Program: CVOS has a training and testing program that ensures that operators have the proper skills and knowledge prior to allowing them to independently operate a process.  Periodic operator re-certification is required.



Computerized Process Simulation: Computerized simulation programs are used for training and troubleshooting and include emergency shutdown and start-up simulations.



Maintenance Procedures: CVOS has specific procedures for maintaining process equiment so that it operates safely.  Plant and unit spefific proceduresfor servicing operating equipment are in place, including a preventive / predictive maintenance and reliability programs.



Maintenance Train

ing: CVOS trains and test mechanics and other craftsmen who perform routine or complex maintenance tasks on process equipment and inspections on operating equipment to ensure they have the required knowledge and skills.



Mechanical Integrity Program: Vessels (including shipping containers) and other process equipment, are periodically tested and inspected to ensure safe operations, following recognized standards and governmental requirements.  



Quality Assurance: CVOS has a system to ensure that purchased equipment and materials meet established engineering standards and specifications.



Process Change Authorizations (Management of Change / PCAs): CVOS has a management sytem to ensure that modifications to a process or faclities are evaluated to ensure continued safe operations.  Design (DSRs) and Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs) are conducted for facility or process changes prior to implementation of the change.



Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs): Reviews conducted just prior to startup to ensure that modified facilities or processes are safe to operate.



Incident Investigation: CVOS has a program to ensure that accidents, incidents, and near misses are properly investigated to determine the root cause as well as contributing causes.  In addition to the investigation, action items resulting from the investigation are communicated site-wide and tracked to completion to prevent recurrence.



Compliance Audits: CVOS conducts audits on a regular basis to verify the provisions set forth under the PSM and RMP rules are being implemented.  These audits are conducted at a minimum of every three years.



Employee Participation: CVON plant has a program to ensure that maintenance and operations personnel are involved in all prevention program elements.  Each operating area has a representative on the Plant Safety Committee (EAGLES - Eliminating Accidents Guarantees Lasting Employee Safety) with this individual acting as the Chair Person for their Area Safety

Committee.  The Contractor Safety Committee chairperson also holds a seat on the EAGLES Plant Safety Committee ensuring that all workers work hand in hand to ensure the safety of all who work here



Contractor Safety Program: The plant has a program to ensure that contractors are properly trained, and uses the Houston Area Contractors Association as a tool to provide the basic HSE training required of a contractor prior to entering a chemical manufacturing facility.  All contractor employees must attend the Houston Area Contractors Association training and be certified through examination prior to arriving at the plant.  In addition to basic training CVON site specific training is required prior to arriving at the plant.  The company has instituted the use of ISNetworld to help screen the contractor companies who work for Equistar Chemicals.  They review the self reported information, verifies its accuracy and then reports the results in an easy-to-follow format. This allows us to select those resources that best meet internal and governmental requirements.



Five Year Accident History



There have been no accidental releases of substances regulated under the RMP rule at this facility over the last 5 years.



Emergency Response



CVOS maintains an integrated contingency plan, which consolidates all of the various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning.  This program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  Furthermore, CVOS coordinates with the community response plan through the North Channel LEPC, as well as the Harris County Office of Emergency Management.  CVOS is also a participating member of the Houston area Channel Industries Mutual Aid (CIMA).





Planned Changes to Improve Safety



The following is a list of improvements CVOS is planning to implement at the facility to help prevent and/or better respond to

accidental chemical releases:



* Continued review and upgrade of safety interlocks system.

* Revalidate all PHAs in accordance with requirementns under RMP and PSM.

* Evaluate and where necessary update facility siting reuqirements for the site.

* Revise the emergency response plan after critiques from resent drills.

* Update facility security following a Security and Vulnerability Survey.

* Continue to utilize the tools of Root Cause Analysis to investigate incidents and develop effective solutions to prevent recurrence.
